bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to James E. Peabody, July 7, 1929

div1.p: Moran thanks Peabody for his efforts in campaigning for compensation for the volunteers. Moran is hesitant to grant Agramonte compensation since he is healthy and, because of being Cuban, was immune from all dangers. Also included is a brief history of Moran's involvement with the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to James E. Peabody, July 7, 1929
div1.opener:
Sun Oil Company,
Ave. Washington Nos. 36-40,
Habana, Cuba,
July 7, 1929.
Prof. James E. Peabody,
The Morris High School,
New York City.
My dear Professor Peabody:
div1.p:
I did not reply immediately to your very kind letter dated Novem-
ber 12, 1928, because I thought perhaps you might drop me a line
after you had had an opportunity to check up on the material I
submitted to you with my letter dated October 29th. . . . . . .
General Kean was at the seat of activities, and I would graceful-
ly accede to his opinion and recollections of the incidents con-
nected with the series of experiments. On the other hand I am sure
Doctor Reed must have given Doctor Kelly all necessary information
for his book “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever”. I am quite sure Gen-
eral Kean's impartiality was evident throughout the many years
which have elapsed between the time of the experiments up to the
present day. Even the Surgeon General's office has had to depend
on General Kean's recollections of the various incidents connect-
ed with the experiments.

While I have had no word from you since the date mentioned I know
you have been very busy in behalf of all of us, culminating in the
passage of the Act signed by the President on February 28th. We
are all under deep and lasting gratitude to you for your consis-
tent fathering of our cause. I am sure that the recognition sought
for us would have failed, as did previous efforts in the same di-
rection, had it not been for your untiring efforts. I am only
sorry that Congress did not see fit to make special and more ade-
quate provision for Mesdames Reed, Lazear and Carroll. I am of
the opinion that all the rest of us are most liberally rewarded
by the legislation enacted into law on February 28th.

I sincerely trust that you will be good enough to consider your
self-imposed task unfinished until justice is done to the three
old ladies mentioned and would suggest that your efforts be con-
fined to the three. Any legislation having in view additional
emoluments for Dr. Agramonte would, I am quite sure, endanger
chances of adequate provision for Mesdames Reed, Carroll and La-
zear. Dr. Agramonte is still in good health and practicing his
profession and his case cannot be compared with those of the wi-
dows of Major Reed, Doctor Lazear and Doctor Carroll; besides he
is a Cuban and, as such, was immune to yellow fever.

I shall be very grateful for a short letter from you and would like
to know whether or not your story of yellow Fever has yet seen the
light. If so, I should like very much and would gratefully ap-
preciate an autographed copy of same.

With my apologies for the imposition on your time and good nature
which perusal of this letter involves, I remain

div1.head: Autobiographical sketch by John J. Moran, July 7, 1929
div1.p:
JOHN J. MORAN. Born in Ireland on March 15th, 1876. Came to the
United States at the tender age of nine. Raised in Ohio. Last
voting residence: New York City. Served in the American Army in
Cuba during the Spanish-American War and with the American Expe-
ditionary Forces in France during the World War. Has lived in
Latin-America since the Spanish-American War with exception of two
years at the University of Virginia and while in the military ser-
vice of the United States during the World War.

CONNECTION WITH YELLOW FEVER EXPERIMENTS: While I was on duty at
the headquarters of General Fitzhugh Lee, as a civilian clerk,
Doctor Walter Reed made it known that he was looking for volun-
teers for his experimental yellow fever camp, later known as Camp
Lazear. I was one of the first, if not the first, to be apprised
of the fact. My intimate friend, Charles Parker, told me that Dr.
Roger Post Ames had informed him to that effect. Parker, knowing
it was my intention to enter the University of Virginia the fol-
lowing year, suggested that the money reward of $500.00 could be
used by me to very good advantage in defraying my expenses during
my four-year course in Medicine at that institution. I told my
friend Parker that I would sleep over the proposition. Next morn-
ing I looked up Dr. Ames and together we called upon Doctor Reed
to whom I made known my intentions of going in for the tests.

Doctor Reed then informed me that he was authorized to pay up to
$500.00 for volunteer subjects. I told him that I would undergo
the tests principally for medical science, for humanity and the
glory of it; that, much as I needed the reward to help pay my ex-
penses at the university next year and until graduation, I could
not place such a low valuation on my life and that should I suc-
cumb to the experiments I did not want posterity to read on my
tombstone “Here lies a man who sold his life for $500.00”. Doc-
tor Reed was profoundly moved. The oft-repeated, “Gentlemen, I
salute you”, was neither expressed nor acted. The moment was
tense and impressive but entirely lacking in the dramatic. Whe-
ther Dr. Howard A. Kelly (author of “Walter Reed and Yellow Fe-
ver”) injected that dramatic passage into the interview or whe-
ther Dr. Reed gave it to him when he was assembling the material
for his book I do not know. That night I informed Kissinger of
my resolution. He was interested and we talked the matter over
until well after midnight with the result that, next morning, he
volunteered for the experiments. So far as I knew at the time,
during the course of the experiments and after the series was over
with, Kissinger and myself were the original volunteers and the
only two stipulating that we should have no material reward.

By the time Camp Lazear was ready for our occupancy there were
several candidates for the bedding and clothing tests, but for a
considerable time Kissinger and myself were the only candidates
for the mosquito route. Later on Spanish immigrants were contra-
cted for at $200.00 each. Doctor Reed offered us our choice of
physician and nurse, regardless of where they were stationed on
the Island. I expressed a preference for Doctor Ames and an army
2.
nurse by the name of Mrs. Gillen, both stationed at Columbia Bar-
racks (Havana). Our camp was established on a neighboring farm
of large acreage where we were strictly isolated and closely guar-
ded. Visitors to the camp were limited to those invited by Doc-
tor Reed and members of the Yellow Fever Commission. Camp life
got to be rather monotonous but I was usually busy attending to
correspondence, notest and reports for Doctor Reed, my tent being
used by him as his office.

The first attempt to inoculate me was made on November 26th, 1900,
and the second on November 29th, a lone mosquito in a test tube
being employed on each occasion and returned to captivity after
feeding on my blood. Results in both instances were NIL. Doctor
Reed then decided to “save” me for his master test in the “infec-
ted Mosquito Building”. Infected mosquitoes in sufficient number
were not available until December 21st, 1900, when fifteen of the
insects were freed in the building. These mosquitoes had bitten
severe cases of yellow fever from five to twenty-four days before.
Five minutes later, that is to say at 12:00 o'clock noon on Decem-
ber 21st, I offered a feast to the fifteen guests, which was
promptly partaken of by eight. With the aid of a hand mirror I
watched them gorge themselves. In the afternoon of the same day
and at the same hour of the following afternoon the remaining se-
ven had their fill. Doctor Reed told me that if this test should
prove successful the mosquito theory would be established in fool-
proof fashion and that the sceptics would not have a leg to stand
on. The sceptics were many in number and most of them prominent
in the medical profession.

On December 25th, 1900, (Christmas morning) I awakened to the fact
that one of the fifteen insects had done its duty, and I knew that
I would be on my way to the yellow fever camp hospital before many
hours. Doctor Reed did not visit the experimental camp until af-
ternoon on Christmas day, and by the time he arrived my tempera-
ture, which I was taking and recording every hour, had risen to
over 103 degrees Fahrenheit. I was packed off in an ambulance
and by midnight my temperature rose to within a fraction of 105.
Dr. Reed and his associates pronounced my attack “a very pretty
case”. I had made up my mind in advance that I would take my med-
icine like a little man, and while the succeeding four or five
days were slightly painful and feverish I think I made but little
complaint. In ten days I was up and around and three days later
I took the blood test (from the veins of a “very pretty case” of
yellow fever) to see if I was immune. I was. It had no effect
on me.

While undergoing treatment I met Doctor Gorgas for the first time.
He was a daily visitor at my bedside, keenly interested in my sym-
ptoms and asking many questions. The Reed and Carroll findings
being no longer a theory but a reality, Dr. Gorgas (then military
health officer of Havana) declared war on the mosquito and its
larvae. Of the entire corps of professional men present in Cuba
at the time of the experiments, including the members of the Yellow
3.
Fever Commission, Doctor Gorgas reaped more fame and glory from
the Reed and Carroll findings than any other man, although he was
merely an observer until the mosquito theory was established. He
attained to great honors and fame during his lifetime, and his
Government promoted him to the highest position within its gift
for men of his profession and career, viz: Surgeon General of the
Army, with rank of Major-General. All this he deserved for his
application of the Reed and Carroll findings, first in Cuba and
later on the Panama Canal, in both of which he conquered yellow
fever. For his services in Cuba he was promoted from Major to
Colonel in the Medical Corps of the Army and for his services on
the Panama Canal he was promoted from Colonel to Major-General.
Shortly before the entry of the United States in the World War he
was appointed Surgeon General of the Army.

There are few who respect more than I do the memory and accompli-
shments of Doctor Gorgas, and if I mention his name in connection
with the experiments I do so for a reason. In contrast with the
honors accorded him during his own lifetime it is a sad commentary
on the Congress of Doctor Reed's day that prompt and suitable re-
cognition was not given him for his great and far-reaching servi-
ces to humanity and medical science and the same criticism applies
to successive Congresses for their failure to make adequate provi-
sion for his widow. The same is no less true with reference to
Mrs. Lazear, whose husband gave up his life -- a brilliant and
promising one in his profession -- for science and humanity. One
cannot help but wonder how much of an education Doctor Lazear's
orphaned children have been able to obtain on the small pension
which Congress voted for their mother and themselves.

Following the death of Doctor Carroll his widow should have been
provided for in a commensurate manner, but here also Congress al-
lotted her a pension which was entirely inadequate. She and her
children deserved a liberal allowance for the prominent part Doc-
tor Carroll played in the discoveries of the Yellow Fever Commiss-
ion. As to the rest of us (the rank and file of those who submit-
ted themselves for the tests) I do not know that we are any poorer
or any richer in the world's goods than we might be had we never
taken them. Yellow fever does not usually leave any disagreeable
traces if one is lucky enough to survive the attack.

Personally I have been a persistent and perennial candidate for
Congressional recognition of a non-material nature, preferably in
the form of a medal. One foreign government has decorated me for
my share in the experiments, but in twenty-eight years my own Gov-
ernment has failed to recognize me in any form. Having declined
material reward at the time I have never felt that it would be good
form to go back on my bargain. Time and again my friends have urg-
ed me to apply for an annuity or pension. I cannot see it from
their point of view. I have always felt that if I applied for an
annuity or allowance it would be equivalent to placing me in a
class with the man who invited the millionaire hunter to breakfast
and then asked him for a hundred thousand dollars to set him up
in business. I went in for the experiments unsolicited and volun-
tarily. If that was a noble and altruistic act I would rather
4.
have my fellow men express their opinion in the premises than
personally crow about it. I do not mind stating that I have
found a great deal of satisfaction in having volunteered for
the experiments. That satisfaction would immediately evapor-
ate, however, if I should ever sign my name to an application
for an annuity or pension.
